WRITING.TEXT: I don't think you understand. At any given point, when you take a test you can have HIV, but the test can show a negative. For some people it can take up to 3 months for the antibodies to show. So if he had unprotected sex 2 weeks before his testing in December, it can show up as negative when he is in fact positive. Take HIV tests into consideration, but they are not determinate, unless you know the person's sex history, you really are delving into unknowns.
The only way that negative test means he truly is negative, is if he had not engaged in any unprotected sex for the past almost 4 months. A test is only truly accurate at 3 months
Do you actually believe a stranger when they say that they are on Prep? Go get tested. Debating whether or not transmission is likely is ridiculous, you won't truly know until you get tested.

I don't know. I mean, what if you were working a low paying job and being able to afford rent on your own was not possible? Sure, if a person did nothing with their life then I can understand, but in some cases there are perfectly good reasons to stay. In Russia and a lot of Asia, if you are not married, it's seen as odd to just move out unless you really had your life together - but even if you did move out, you would have to be close to family. I moved out at 18 - had a decent paying job and I was living with my boyfriend. The only thing that made my family shut up over asking me why I even moved out was when I got married. *shrug* different cultures do shit differently

It depends on what you are losing. Once all the fat is gone, the muscle just vanishes really quickly. People with AN get what is called hypermetabolism where they require more calories than the normal person. If you aren't eating at all, this will just chew away at your muscle. I know this from experience. I had a low body fat percentage to begin with, and went from 120 pounds to 77 pounds in 5 months. I was also bedridden and couldn't walk because I was so weak.

I cheated. I wanted my boyfriend to break up with me because I was about to commit suicide. He didn't, so I gave myself anorexia and tried cheating again so he would get the picture. In my opinion it was easier for him to leave me over me doing a shitty thing, rather than to love me and watch me die. Sly bastard proposed to me and we've been married for 5 years now. If you're wondering why I didn't just tell him that I wanted to break up - if you love someone a lot, and they know it, telling them you want to break up is really unconvincing. I had told him, and he was right in not believing me. Also I had some serious mental health problems going on at the time so it was hard to even tell if I was being serious or it was my psychosis.
Obviously this is very different to what you went through. In my opinion - forget about what he did, and instead focus on how you feel about the situation and realise what you feel comfortable with doing. His reasons are irrelevant, your reasons for staying or leaving are the most important - the ball is in your court, so don't even spare him the consideration of 'why' he did it. Just think to yourself if staying together - going through couple's counselling etc and if the goodness of your relationship is worth keeping, or if you are better off on your own or with someone else. I know you are trying to blame yourself, but if he never vocalised that there were fissures in your relationship, how would you have known? At the end of the day, he committed the action and now it hinges on you to decide if the relationship is worth saving.

I did SLP as my undergrad. If you want employment, you don't do SLP. Full-time for most of us was working 3 days a week, earning a pay that was fairly average and unrewarding, not to mention the career progression is shit and the stability of work was abysmal. I was coming into work - at a major hospital btw - wondering if I was going to be let go within the next year. Most of my friends (over 2 years later) have still not found stable work in the field, going freelance and earning a pittance whilst they work retail.
It's an extremely underutilised field.

You can get maxillofacial surgery. Depending on what your jaw is like now, it may involve extending and reshaping your jaw. It's quite an extensive surgery involving cutting up your jaw and reshaping and rearranging it using titanium plating. It's the most effective surgical option. You can also get some orthodontal work that helps extend the jaw, but once you're over 20 it's effectiveness decreases quite a bit, and surgery becomes the most, if not only, viable option.
Since jaw surgery is really invasive and is more for cases of TMJ, overbite and underbite, some surgeons may recommend a combination of liposculpture for your jaw and neck, and implants or fillers. Of course this all depends on what you need and what the surgeon thinks will work with you, the downside to this option is you can't extend the jaw forward, however rather than 1-2 months of healing, you'd have at most 2 weeks of healing.

While I don't have experience with this, I am a nurse. Bouncing back after chemo and surgery takes quite a while, some patients still feel ill until around 18 months. There is a very large psychological component tied to what you went through as well. Are there any therapists you can see to help you out with the difficult time you are going through (hopefully a psychologist from the hospital)?

This is funny to me, because my family has always been anti-war. In fact, my great grandparents studied medicine in the US and the UK. Hiroshima and Nagasaki did not only affect Japanese people, a lot of Americans in Japan also died and were wounded and now receive free medical care in Japan. I can never imagine the US doing the same for foreign visitors impacted by war.
Just like how not a lot of people wish to follow Trump to the grave, a lot of Japanese did not like their own government. Think for a moment, if you faced war consequences due to a president you did not vote for and someone said that you deserved it because of that government - the one you did not endorse, how would you feel?

Thanks for the question. This is going to be long, so strap yourself in!
This really depends on when and who in the family, as well as who is doing the discrimination. My grandmother's family did not experience stigma since her parents were doctors in Hiroshima she was born in Tokyo, a month or so after the bombing and was born without obvious defect, in fact she was relatively healthy most of her life so she wasn't seen as a survivor of Hiroshima.
It wasn't until my mother and her sister were born that it became clear something was wrong. Mom's sister died as an infant, she had underdeveloped organs and tumours. My mother had leukaemia as a child and bone problems. My grandmother was granted Hibakusha status meaning they were recognised victims of the bombings - her and my mother received government payment and support as well as free healthcare.
But socially is a different thing, while they had government support and medical professionals all agree to help them, there was societal discrimination. Mom couldn't go to school, and when they moved to Osaka, she was still isolated from other students. Getting into university was hard for her, so much so she moved to Russia where she met my dad. She ironically studied nuclear medicine, and when she went back to Japan no one would hire her.
My mother could not get IVF in Japan, and no one wanted to marry my parents. So she had to permanently move to Russia. As horrible as it all sounds, my mother never felt resentful. In Japan to marry means to have children and my mother having children meant passing on her flawed genes, they also believed that her conditions were contagious hence why she was always isolated or discriminated.
As for now, her youngest half brother is an active pacifist who joins rallies and events in support of recognition of Japanese war crimes and the discrimination against bombing survivors. I know children of hibakusha who experience discrimination - they can't find work because employers think they will be sick or die, they can't find partners because of the same reason and because they 'can't have children'. Essentially it is treated like having a disability except a lot of us are completely fine. I'm lucky in that when people know that I am descended from Hibakusha, I am not treated with disrespect, because I'm gay and won't pass it on. If anything, I've faced more discrimination in the US because I'm a living example of the atrocities committed, just as I would imagine the descendants of comfort women would upset some people in Japan. It's always wonderful hearing that I should never have been born and that my great grandparents should have died.

That's exactly the thing. Both have committed atrocities, but if America fails to acknowledge what it did, so will Japan.
I'm on the other side of this story. My mother's side of the family were victims to the bombing of Hiroshima. My grandmother was born with genetic defects causing her to pass on a variety of cancers through the family line. My mother died, having lived through infertility, bone issues and after I was born (5the IVF attempt) she spent most of my life in hospital getting chemotherapy, and I myself have had two cancer scares and I'm only 24.
War does no one good and we should stop pretending and pointing fingers and just own up to the nature of war - an act against humanity where people on all sides commit inhumane things. Rather than just sugar-coating history with stories of valour and camaraderie.

Don't worry. You really are not alone. I worked for a year as a speech pathologist and was crazy underemployed- only had work 3 days a week. I kept applying for full time positions but no one wanted to take me on/there just wasn't much available. So I geared up, got another degree and now work as a nurse. For 3 whole years I was stuck working part time and casual as a speech pathologist and even when studying again, I was still applying to full time roles with the hope of just dropping the nursing degree and doing what I set my passions to. Never landed.
Sometimes you'll just have to retrain or move because there isn't anything out there for you

Sort of. Having a health related degree put me into an accelerated nursing course which condensed 4 years into 2 years. I feel like I had the benefit of knowing how to conduct myself on placements and working directly with patients, but at the same time I feel like nursing is more meeting KPIs, whereas speech pathology was essentially a desk job that was more patient focussed.
However, I'm a surgery nurse, my interactions with patients are restricted to them unconscious on the operating table, lol. But it is beneficial in getting your foot in the door in a hospital and health system since you will have been familiar with a specialised sector. I do believe it helped me get into surgery and be able to take on an advanced role - realistically, I can work specifically within neurosurgery and ENTs as I have the background knowledge and experience for that on a theoretical level.
I can also work as a rehab nurse for those with speech issues - assuming my role as speech pathologist again, but with the ability to medicate and treat. But I chose to work in surgery, mostly because no one else wants to and I felt maybe this was all a sign to take on a role that was desperately starved for people.
The pay is shit, other nurses think you're incompetent and the hours are long, but the surgery team is such a tight knit family and I can always rely on having work.

Agreed. I experienced the same thing with psychology and becoming a speech pathologist. All of my work was casual or part-time, and I worked at a major hospital. So I went back to uni and now work as a full-time registered nurse - there were only 190 positions in my program at USYD, about 120 graduated, and I was the only one who became an operating room nurse. There is a massive shortage in this sector, but because of its unpopularity, universities are not opening up the course. Honestly, I've worked overtime almost every single day since I started and I am really dreading the 14 hour shift I have this coming Monday, having more people would really help.
